metadata.icd10_code: F1x.980 / TCode (varies by substance; use substance-specific code)

content.description: Substance/Medication-Induced Anxiety Disorder is characterized by prominent anxiety, panic, obsessions/compulsions, or related physiological arousal that develop during or soon after substance intoxication, withdrawal, or medication exposure. Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment and are not better explained by a primary anxiety disorder.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Prominent anxiety, panic attacks, or related symptoms. B. Evidence that symptoms developed during/soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal, or after exposure to a medication; the substance/medication is capable of producing such symptoms. C. Not better explained by an independent anxiety disorder (e.g., symptoms preceded use, persist well beyond expected time course, or there is a history of recurrent non–substance-related episodes). D. Does not occur exclusively during a delirium. E. Causes distress/impairment.
content.prevalence: Varies by substance, dose, route, and setting; commonly seen with stimulants, cannabis (especially high-THC), alcohol withdrawal, corticosteroids, thyroid hormone excess, and certain antidepressants during initiation/titration.
content.age_of_onset: Any age, typically acute onset temporally linked to new exposure, dose change, intoxication, or withdrawal.
content.prognosis: Often resolves with cessation or dose adjustment of the implicated agent and acute management of withdrawal/intoxication. Persistent anxiety suggests an underlying primary anxiety disorder or prolonged substance effects.

history_psychosocial: Detailed timeline linking symptom onset to substance use, withdrawal, or medication changes (start, stop, dose, route).
Past anxiety history to distinguish primary vs. induced disorder; functional impact and safety behaviors.
medical_assessment: Targeted physical exam and vitals; review of medications (including OTCs, supplements) and substances (caffeine, nicotine, cannabis, stimulants, alcohol, hallucinogens).
Consider labs/EKG/toxicology based on suspected agent (e.g., TSH/free T4 for thyroid; electrolytes; pregnancy test when relevant).
standardized_measures: GAD-7 or Panic Disorder Severity Scale (for baseline/severity tracking)
CIWA-Ar or COWS when alcohol/opioid withdrawal suspected
differential_diagnosis: Primary anxiety disorders (GAD, panic disorder, social anxiety)
Delirium or psychotic disorders secondary to substances
Akathisia (antipsychotics, SSRIs), serotonin toxicity, caffeine intoxication

emotional_cognitive: Intense anxiety, fear, or dread temporally linked to a substance/medication
physical: Palpitations, tremor, sweating, chest tightness, shortness of breath
behavioral: Avoidance of triggers, emergency care seeking, reassurance seeking
Substance redosing to relieve withdrawal-related anxiety

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms present but manageable; minimal functional impairment.
severity_levels.moderate: Noticeable distress/impairment; may require medication adjustment and brief pharmacotherapy.
severity_levels.severe: Marked impairment or risk (e.g., severe withdrawal, suicidality, medical instability) requiring urgent care.

biological: High autonomic reactivity or thyroid dysfunction
psychological: Prior panic or adverse drug reaction
environmental: High-dose or rapid titration of activating agents (stimulants, SSRIs/SNRIs, bupropion)
Polysubstance use, high-THC cannabis concentrates, heavy caffeine/nicotine

impact_on_life.school_work: Missed days, reduced productivity, impaired concentration.
impact_on_life.social: Avoidance of activities or settings associated with use or panic.
impact_on_life.emotional: Anticipatory anxiety, demoralization, possible depressive symptoms.

acute_management: Identify and discontinue or taper the offending agent when clinically safe; treat intoxication/withdrawal per protocols.
Short-term benzodiazepines may be used for severe alcohol/benzodiazepine withdrawal–related anxiety; avoid or tightly limit in SUD.
Beta-blockers for somatic hyperarousal or antipsychotic-induced akathisia (e.g., propranolol); consider anticholinergics for EPS as indicated.
psychotherapy: CBT targeting anxiety sensitivity, interoceptive exposure, and relapse-prevention skills.
Motivational interviewing and contingency management for co-occurring SUD.
medications: For persistent symptoms after washout: SSRIs/SNRIs with slow titration; consider buspirone or hydroxyzine as nonaddictive options.
Avoid interacting/activating agents when possible; coordinate with prescribers for dose adjustments or alternatives.
lifestyle_interventions: Reduce/avoid caffeine, nicotine, and other stimulants; sleep hygiene; regular exercise.
Psychoeducation on timing of medication side effects and withdrawal phenomena.
care_coordination: Collaborate with primary care/addiction medicine/pharmacy for deprescribing plans and monitoring.
Safety planning for severe anxiety, suicidality, or medical risk.

treatment_goals: Eliminate or reduce exposure to the causative substance/medication.
Stabilize acute anxiety and withdrawal symptoms.
Prevent relapse of substance use and recurrence of induced anxiety.
Address residual anxiety and restore full functioning.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing anxiety solely to life stress without mapping to medication/substance timeline.
Failure to recognize activating side effects during antidepressant/stimulant initiation or dose changes.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling primary anxiety disorder as induced despite symptoms preceding exposure or persisting well beyond expected time course.
Normal transient activation during early SSRI/SNRI titration pathologized without impairment.

substance_class_examples: Alcohol, cannabis, phencyclidine/other hallucinogen, inhalant, sedative/hypnotic/anxiolytic, amphetamine or other stimulant, cocaine, other/unknown substance, medication (e.g., corticosteroids, thyroid hormone, antidepressants)

warning_signs: New-onset anxiety shortly after starting or increasing a medication dose.
Worsening anxiety during periods of reduced use or abstinence (withdrawal).
Severe autonomic symptoms, chest pain, or suicidality.
self_help_strategies: Track timing of symptoms relative to doses and substances; share with clinicians.
Avoid or limit caffeine, nicotine, high-THC products, and nonprescribed stimulants.
Use paced breathing/grounding; maintain sleep schedule; gradual aerobic activity.
real_life_examples: An adult develops intense panic after starting high-THC vaping; symptoms remit after cessation and CBT for anxiety sensitivity.
A patient experiences severe anxiety during alcohol withdrawal; treated with a supervised benzodiazepine taper and relapse-prevention therapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek urgent care for severe withdrawal, chest pain, confusion, or suicidality. Consult a clinician when anxiety begins after a new medication/substance, with dose changes, or persists despite stopping the agent.

positive_factors: Rapid identification and cessation of the causative agent
Short duration of exposure and absence of SUD
Good engagement in CBT and relapse-prevention
challenging_factors: Ongoing use or physiological dependence with withdrawal risk
Polysubstance use or high-THC/high-dose stimulant exposure
Comorbid depressive or primary anxiety disorders
Medical comorbidities (e.g., hyperthyroidism), poor insight, or limited follow-up
